page.title: 13HOLME PIERREPONT HALL
page.content: { Holme}(the Saxon word means island) is a gravel bank raised above the flood level of the River Trent, and is recorded in the{Domesday Book.}It is surrounded by{gravel pits,}some still being worked. The Hall is now the home of Robin Brackenbury and his wife, Elizabeth, herself a descendant of Sir William Pierrepont, who built it in the{early {16th century.} It was the{first manor house in the {country to be built of brick,}and the long red front has hardly changed to this day. The inside was left a wreck after being requisitoned in two world wars, and a lot is being done to restore it, to eliminate dry rot and replant the gardens. The Hall is open to the public on four afternoons a week during the summer (entrance fee - Â£1.20)
